span.span: Research Center for Information Science and Education, Hiroshima University

div.p: The studies of the quantum corrections for the anisotropy parameter, Î·(=Î¾R/Î¾B)annotatedğœ‚absentsubscriptğœ‰ğ‘…subscriptğœ‰ğµitalic-eta OPEN:( RELOP:equals italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)\eta(=\xi_{R}/\xi_{B}), for the improved actions, Î²â¢(C0â¢Lâ¢(Plaq.)+C1â¢Lâ¢(Rect.))ğ›½subscriptğ¶0ğ¿Plaq.subscriptğ¶1ğ¿Rect.italic-beta OPEN:( italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-L OPEN:( ATOM:Plaq. CLOSE:) ADDOP:plus italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-L OPEN:( ATOM:Rect. CLOSE:) CLOSE:)\beta(C_{0}L(\mbox{Plaq.})+C_{1}L(\mbox{Rect.})), are proceeded in the medium to strong coupling region on anisotropic lattices. The global features for the Î·ğœ‚italic-eta\eta parameters as a function of Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta and the coefficient C1subscriptğ¶1italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endC_{1} have been clarified. It has been found by the perturbative analysis that as C1subscriptğ¶1italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endC_{1} decreases, the slope of the Î·â¢(Î²)ğœ‚ğ›½italic-eta OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:)\eta(\beta) becomes less steep and for the actions whose C1subscriptğ¶1italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endC_{1} is less than -0.1600.160ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.160-0.160, Î·ğœ‚italic-eta\eta decreases as Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta decreases, contrary to the case of the standard action. In the medium to strong coupling region, the Î·ğœ‚italic-eta\eta parameter begins to increase as Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta decreases for all C1subscriptğ¶1italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endC_{1}. This means that for the actions with C1<-0.160subscriptğ¶10.160italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.160C_{1}<-0.160, the one-loop perturbative results for Î·ğœ‚italic-eta\eta break down qualitatively and the Î·ğœ‚italic-eta\eta parameters have a dip. As a result of this dip structure the Î·ğœ‚italic-eta\eta for Iwasakiâ€™s action remains close to unity in the wide range of Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta, which means that quantum corrections for the anisotropy parameters are small for it.

The advantage of using improved actions has been recognized in many area of lattice simulations; at the same time the merits of using anisotropic lattice have been well understood[1]. Then we had started the study of the anisotropic properties for the improved actions[2]. The improved actions we study in this work consist of terms

semantics.annotation: italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu PUNCT:, italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-beta OPEN:( italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-L OPEN:( ATOM:Plaq. CLOSE:) POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu PUNCT:, italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-L OPEN:( ATOM:Rect. CLOSE:) POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu PUNCT:, italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)

div.p:
where Lâ¢(Plaq.)ğ¿Plaq.italic-L OPEN:( ATOM:Plaq. CLOSE:)L(\mbox{Plaq.}) and Lâ¢(Rect.)ğ¿Rect.italic-L OPEN:( ATOM:Rect. CLOSE:)L(\mbox{Rect.}) represent plaquette and 6-link rectangular loops respectively, and C0subscriptğ¶0italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endC_{0} and C1subscriptğ¶1italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endC_{1} satisfies C0+8â‹…C1=1subscriptğ¶0â‹…8subscriptğ¶11italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus NUMBER:8 MULOP:cdot italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1C_{0}+8\cdot C_{1}=1. Our improved action covers
i) tree level Symanzikâ€™s action(C1=-1/12subscriptğ¶1112italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:12C_{1}=-1/12)[3],
ii) Iwasakiâ€™s action(C1=-0.331subscriptğ¶10.331italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.331C_{1}=-0.331)[4],
iii) QCDTAROâ€™s action(C1=-1.409subscriptğ¶11.409italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1.409C_{1}=-1.409)[5]
etc.
For these classes of improved actions the anisotropic lattice is formulated in the same way as in the case of standard plaquette action[1]. We introduce the coupling constant, gÏƒsubscriptğ‘”ğœitalic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:endg_{\sigma}, (gÏ„subscriptğ‘”ğœitalic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:endg_{\tau}) and lattice spacing, aÏƒsubscriptğ‘ğœitalic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:enda_{\sigma}, (aÏ„subscriptğ‘ğœitalic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:enda_{\tau}) in space (temperature) direction. With these parameters, the action on the anisotropic lattice is written as,

semantics.annotation: italic-S RELOP:equals italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:cdot italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:cdot italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:,

div.p:
where Î²Ïƒ=gÏƒ-2â¢Î¾R-1subscriptğ›½ğœsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğœ2superscriptsubscriptğœ‰ğ‘…1italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\beta_{\sigma}=g_{\sigma}^{-2}\xi_{R}^{-1}, Î²Ï„=gÏ„-2â¢Î¾Rsubscriptğ›½ğœsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğœ2subscriptğœ‰ğ‘…italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\beta_{\tau}=g_{\tau}^{-2}\xi_{R} and Î¾R=aÏƒ/aÏ„subscriptğœ‰ğ‘…subscriptğ‘ğœsubscriptğ‘ğœitalic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\xi_{R}=a_{\sigma}/a_{\tau}.
In the weak coupling expansions, the Î·ğœ‚italic-eta\eta parameter has been written as follows,

semantics.annotation: italic-eta RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus italic-N MULOP:cdot italic-alpha OPEN:( italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) MULOP:divide italic-beta ADDOP:plus italic-O OPEN:( italic-g POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) PERIOD:.

div.p: The behavior of Î±â¢(Î¾R,C1)ğ›¼subscriptğœ‰ğ‘…subscriptğ¶1italic-alpha OPEN:( italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)\alpha(\xi_{R},C_{1}) had already been reported at lat98[2], which we will show in Fig.1.

figure.figcaption: Figure 1: The coefficients Î±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alpha as a function of C1subscriptğ¶1italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endC_{1}

div.p:
We have found that Î±â¢(Î¾R,C1)ğ›¼subscriptğœ‰ğ‘…subscriptğ¶1italic-alpha OPEN:( italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)\alpha(\xi_{R},C_{1}) changes sign around C1âˆ¼-0.160similar-tosubscriptğ¶10.160italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.160C_{1}\sim-0.160. Namely in the weak coupling region, for the Iwasakiâ€™s and QCDTAROâ€™s actions, the Î·ğœ‚italic-eta\eta parameter is less than unity contrary to the case of the standard plaquette action.
The natural question is what is the behavior of Î·ğœ‚italic-eta\eta in the intermediate to weak coupling region, for those improved actions.

Numerically, the parameter Î·ğœ‚italic-eta\eta is calculated by the relation Î·=Î¾R/Î¾Bğœ‚subscriptğœ‰ğ‘…subscriptğœ‰ğµitalic-eta RELOP:equals italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\eta=\xi_{R}/\xi_{B}[6][7][8] , where Î¾Bsubscriptğœ‰ğµitalic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\xi_{B} is a bare anisotropy parameter which appears in the action,

semantics.annotation: italic-S RELOP:equals italic-beta OPEN:( FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i NUMBER:4 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) PUNCT:,

div.p: while the renormalized anisotropy parameter is defined by Î¾R=aÏƒ/aÏ„subscriptğœ‰ğ‘…subscriptğ‘ğœsubscriptğ‘ğœitalic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\xi_{R}=a_{\sigma}/a_{\tau}. For the probe of the scale for the space and temperature direction, we use the lattice potential in these directions. The lattice potential in temperature direction is defined by Wilson loops in space-temperature plane,

semantics.annotation: italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-p PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals OPFUNCTION:natural-logarithm OPEN:( FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-W POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-p PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) ARG:end ARG:start italic-W POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-p ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) ARG:end CLOSE:) PERIOD:.

div.p:
The potential in the space direction is defined in a similar way.
The simulations are mainly done on the 123Ã—24superscript12324NUMBER:12 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:times NUMBER:2412^{3}\times 24 lattice for Î¾R=2.0subscriptğœ‰ğ‘…2.0italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:2.0\xi_{R}=2.0, and for some Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta on 163Ã—32superscript16332NUMBER:16 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:times NUMBER:3216^{3}\times 32 lattice to study the size dependences.
The method of determination of Î·ğœ‚italic-eta\eta is explained in some detail by the examples of Î²=4.5ğ›½4.5italic-beta RELOP:equals NUMBER:4.5\beta=4.5 for Iwasakiâ€™s improved action.
We fix Î¾R=2subscriptğœ‰ğ‘…2italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:2\xi_{R}=2, and calculate the rate

semantics.annotation: italic-R OPEN:( italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-p PUNCT:, italic-r CLOSE:) RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-p PUNCT:, italic-r CLOSE:) ARG:end ARG:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-p PUNCT:, italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-t CLOSE:) ARG:end

div.p: at Î¾B=2.0,2.1,2,2subscriptğœ‰ğµ2.02.122italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:2.0 PUNCT:, NUMBER:2.1 PUNCT:, NUMBER:2 PUNCT:, NUMBER:2\xi_{B}=2.0,2.1,2,2. The results for Î¾B=2.1subscriptğœ‰ğµ2.1italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:2.1\xi_{B}=2.1 are shown in the Fig.2 for each pğ‘italic-pp and rğ‘Ÿitalic-rr.

figure.figcaption: Figure 2: Ratio Râ¢(p,r)ğ‘…ğ‘ğ‘Ÿitalic-R OPEN:( italic-p PUNCT:, italic-r CLOSE:)R(p,r) for Î²=4.5ğ›½4.5italic-beta RELOP:equals NUMBER:4.5\beta=4.5 and Î¾B=2.1subscriptğœ‰ğµ2.1italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:2.1\xi_{B}=2.1

div.p: For these Râ¢(Î¾B)ğ‘…subscriptğœ‰ğµitalic-R OPEN:( italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)R(\xi_{B}) we have made the interpolation by the second order polynomial in Î¾Bsubscriptğœ‰ğµitalic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\xi_{B} and solve the point where R=1ğ‘…1italic-R RELOP:equals NUMBER:1R=1 is satisfied. Then the Î·ğœ‚italic-eta\eta is obtained for each pğ‘italic-pp and rğ‘Ÿitalic-rr. The results for the Î·ğœ‚italic-eta\eta are shown in Fig.3.

figure.figcaption: Figure 3: Î·â¢(pÃ—r)ğœ‚ğ‘ğ‘Ÿitalic-eta OPEN:( italic-p MULOP:times italic-r CLOSE:)\eta(p\times r) at Î²=4.5ğ›½4.5italic-beta RELOP:equals NUMBER:4.5\beta=4.5 and Î¾R=2.0subscriptğœ‰ğ‘…2.0italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:2.0\xi_{R}=2.0

div.p:
It is found that for pÃ—râ‰¥15ğ‘ğ‘Ÿ15italic-p MULOP:times italic-r RELOP:greater-than-or-equals NUMBER:15p\times r\geq 15, Î·ğœ‚italic-eta\eta is almost flat. For the flat region, we take the average of them. The errors are estimated by the Jackknife method. The same analysis has been repeated for other Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta and for the other Improved actions.
In order to check the size dependences, the simulations are carried out on 163Ã—32superscript16332NUMBER:16 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:times NUMBER:3216^{3}\times 32 lattice at Î²=21.0ğ›½21.0italic-beta RELOP:equals NUMBER:21.0\beta=21.0 and 3.53.5NUMBER:3.53.5 for the Iwasakiâ€™s improved action. It is found that at Î²=21.0ğ›½21.0italic-beta RELOP:equals NUMBER:21.0\beta=21.0 the size dependence is not small but at Î²=3.5ğ›½3.5italic-beta RELOP:equals NUMBER:3.5\beta=3.5 it is quite small. Therefore for the intermediate to strong coupling region, the simulation is carried out on 123Ã—24superscript12324NUMBER:12 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:times NUMBER:2412^{3}\times 24 lattice. All the results are summarized in Fig.4.

figure.figcaption: Figure 4: All the results for Î·â¢(Î²,C1)ğœ‚ğ›½subscriptğ¶1italic-eta OPEN:( italic-beta PUNCT:, italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)\eta(\beta,C_{1}). The results for the standard action is from Ref.6

div.p:
âˆ™âˆ™MULOP:bullet\bullet Iwasakiâ€™s Action
The Î·ğœ‚italic-eta\eta parameter has a shallow dip at Î²âˆ¼6.0similar-toğ›½6.0italic-beta RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:6.0\beta\sim 6.0 and then blows up towards the small Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta region. The prediction by the one loop perturbative calculation breaks down qualitatively. As a results of this behavior the Î·âˆ¼1similar-toğœ‚1italic-eta RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:1\eta\sim 1 in the wide range of Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta.
The results for Î¾R=3subscriptğœ‰ğ‘…3italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:3\xi_{R}=3 are also shown in the Fig.4. It is found that the qualitative behavior is the same but the dip around Î²=6.0ğ›½6.0italic-beta RELOP:equals NUMBER:6.0\beta=6.0 becomes deeper. This means that the renormalization of the anisotropy parameter is larger for larger Î¾Rsubscriptğœ‰ğ‘…italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\xi_{R}.

âˆ™âˆ™MULOP:bullet\bullet Tree-level Symanzikâ€™s Action and the action with C1=-0.16subscriptğ¶10.16italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.16C_{1}=-0.16
The Î·ğœ‚italic-eta\eta for Symanzikâ€™s action is qualitatively the same as those of the standard action[8]; namely it increases monotonically as Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta decreases. But the slope is less steep and then the value of Î·ğœ‚italic-eta\eta is smaller than the standard action at a given Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta.
For the action with C1=-0.16subscriptğ¶10.16italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.16C_{1}=-0.16, it has been found that Î±=0ğ›¼0italic-alpha RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\alpha=0, namely the renormalization of the anisotropy parameter is zero in the weak coupling perturbative calculations[2]. The Î·ğœ‚italic-eta\eta in the intermediate to strong coupling region shows similar behavior with the standard plaquette action and Symanzikâ€™s action. But again the slope becomes less steep.

âˆ™âˆ™MULOP:bullet\bullet Global features of Î·â¢(Î²,C1)ğœ‚ğ›½subscriptğ¶1italic-eta OPEN:( italic-beta PUNCT:, italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)\eta(\beta,C_{1})
The calculation with the QCDTAROâ€™s action is not carried out yet. But we have found the global structure of the Î·ğœ‚italic-eta\eta parameter as a function of Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta and C1subscriptğ¶1italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endC_{1}. The interesting point is that the for the action with C1<-0.16subscriptğ¶10.16italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.16C_{1}<-0.16, the Î·ğœ‚italic-eta\eta once decreases and then increases with decreasing Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta. As a result of this behavior the Î·ğœ‚italic-eta\eta stays close to one in the wide range of Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta for Iwasakiâ€™s improved action. This may be a good features for the numerical simulations.

âˆ™âˆ™MULOP:bullet\bullet Further works
The calculation of the Î·ğœ‚italic-eta\eta at stronger coupling region and the other Î¾R=0.5,1.5,3.05.0subscriptğœ‰ğ‘…0.51.53.05.0italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.5 PUNCT:, NUMBER:1.5 PUNCT:, NUMBER:3.05.0\xi_{R}=0.5,1.5,3.05.0 etc are now under study. We are preparing to use the smeared Wilson loops for the simulation in the stronger coupling region.
We are starting the calculation of the lattice spacing ağ‘italic-aa as a function of Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta on the anisotropic lattices.
The behavior of Î·ğœ‚italic-eta\eta with smaller C1subscriptğ¶1italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endC_{1} like QCDTAROâ€™s action, is also an interesting problem.
We are preparing the simulations of physical quantities on an anisotropic lattice with improved actions. The targets are heavy quark spectroscopy, transport coefficients of quark gluon plasma etc.

ACKNOWLEDGMENTS
The present work has been done with SX-4 at RCNP and VX-4 at Yamagata. We are grateful for the members of RCNP for warm hospitality and kind supports.

Y. Iwasaki, Nucl. Phys. B258(1985), 141; Univ. of Tsukuba preprint UTHEP-118(1983)
QCD-TARO Collaboration, Ph. de Forcrand et al. hep-lat/9806008
G.Burgers et al., Nucl. Phys. B204, 587, 1988
J.Engels, F.Karsch and T. Scheideler hep-lat/9905002
